fields.summary: Use another means to configure admin tools with CLC service endpoints

comments.body: If you use DNS to resolve the bootstrap or properties services they will resolve to the services on a UFS host, not on the cloud controller. The empyrean service on the cloud controller should be used for correct functionality.
In that case the DNS queries are returning incorrect results and also need fixing.
[~gholms], the current behaviour is expected and is the least surprising as the DNS name should resolve to a host that is most likely to be public.
How can that possibly make sense when the machines they resolve to cannot be used for correct functionality?

Simply put, when I ask the cloud to tell me where to find an endpoint I expect it to point to an endpoint that works.  If it instead knowingly points me at something that only partially works or doesn't work at all then I can't get my job done as a cloud administrator and we need to re-think our approach to client configuration.
Let's remove the path requirement from the internal services.
EUCA-11422 tracks re-thinking our approach to admin tool configuration.

Internal Query API services now resolve using the host name when no path is present:

Bootstrap/empyrean:

{code}

Note: dns.enable must also be 'true'</euca:description><euca:defaultValue/><euca:readOnly>false</euca:readOnly></euca:item><euca:item><euca:name>dns.ns.enabled</euca:name><euca:value>true</euca:value><euca:description>Enable the NS resolver.  Note: dns.enable must also be 'true'</euca:description><euca:defaultValue/><euca:readOnly>false</euca:readOnly></euca:item><euca:item><euca:name>dns.recursive.enabled</euca:name><euca:value>true</euca:value><euca:description>Enable the recursive DNS resolver.  Note: dns.enable must also be 'true'</euca:description><euca:defaultValue/><euca:readOnly>false</euca:readOnly></euca:item><euca:item><euca:name>dns.services.enabled</euca:name><euca:value>true</euca:value><euca:description>Enable the service topology resolver.  Note: dns.enable must also be 'true'</euca:description><euca:defaultValue/><euca:readOnly>false</euca:readOnly></euca:item><euca:item><euca:name>dns.split_horizon.enabled</euca:name><euca:value>true</euca:value><euca:description>Enable the split-horizon DNS resolution for internal instance public DNS name queries. If set, the region name to expect as the second label in the DNS name. For example, to treat your Eucalyptus install like a region named 'eucalyptus', set this value to 'eucalyptus'.  Then, e.g., autoscaling.eucalyptus.amazonaws.com will resolve to the service address when using this DNS server.</euca:description><euca:defaultValue/><euca:readOnly>false</euca:readOnly></euca:item><euca:item><euca:name>dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_default_regions</euca:name><euca:value>false</euca:value><euca:description>Enable spoofing of the default AWS DNS names, e.g., ec2.amazonaws.com would resolve to the ENABLED cloud controller.</euca:description><euca:defaultValue/><euca:readOnly>false</euca:readOnly></euca:item><euca:item><euca:name>dns.spoof_regions.spoof_aws_regions</euca:name><euca:value>false</euca:value><euca:description>Enable spoofing for the normal AWS regions, too. e.g., ec2.us-east-1.amazonaws.com would resolve to the ENABLED cloud controller.</euca:description><euca:defaultValue/><euca:readOnly>false</euca:readOnly></euca:item><euca:item><euca:name>dns.tcp.timeout_seconds</euca:name><euca:value>30</euca:value><euca:description>Parameter controlling tcp handler timeout in seconds.</euca:description><euca:defaultValue/><euca:readOnly>false</euca:readOnly></euca:item></euca:properties></euca:DescribePropertiesResponseType>
